displayed_text: Patient: Yes. Doctor: We are beyond that. Do you have a doctor that you’re seeing? Patient: Yes I got a doctor P____ and I talk to him and he probably refer me… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …to someone. I don’t know if to you… Doctor: Right, right. Patient: …probably they do it here or? Doctor: We do it here but I’ll let him refer you to whom he wants to refer you to. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh no we don’t do it uh… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …we just specialize in prostate getting you better.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Family Member: But say if his rib spots start- causing him pain - Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Family Member: Can they go in specifically with a proton or? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Would it be needed, a proton be needed, or can regular radiation take care of it? Doctor: So typically it’s just regular radiation. So right now as far as I’m aware it’s sort of like isolated rib treatment for proton is not commonplace. Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: So we don’t, I don’t think that’s part of their indication. Um, but, you know, we’d have to ask the proton guys for that. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Well then being that the radiation is site specific Doctor: Mm Mmm. Patient: and you’ve created this area- Doctor: Yep.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: when you’re on a trial we can sometimes blame the new drug for that symptom and then that drug gets a black eye. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So companies want to make sure that you’re good to go on and they’re not going to get a black eye because there’s something going on that’s not related to what they’re doing. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Yes, understand. Doctor: So that’s important that we get the pulmonary evaluation, what they’re thinking. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It’s likely that we probably need new pictures to sort of see what your liver is doing. And I think it’s time in some ways because you know the Enzalutamide is not controlling your PSA, and you’re ARV7 positive it’s likely that if we got more pictures we would see more cancer. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I need to know what’s going on with your lungs because some of the treatments that we would talk about have toxicity to the lungs as one of the main side effects. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Not for now. Okay. That’s good news. Doctor: You know, but someday maybe. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I mean, it is an effective thing we use, but I think we have other things to try before. Family Member: Awesome. (sighs) Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. So, are we, or why, are we trying these other things because - and it could be both answers - because you want to know? Or because, they’re the most effective options for me? Doctor: So. (Pause) Patient: I don’t want to compromise your ethical considerations. Doctor: So, in the realm of standard treatment, the two treatments that we have that are new hormonal treatments, we call them “Second Line Treatments.” So, the, the Lupron/Eligard is the first one. We would add a second one. Both of those have been tested in big clinical trials, and both of those showed an improvement in survival for a large group of men. It wasn’t a huge improvement. Um. But it reduced your risk of dying of prostate cancer by about thirty percent. The survival improvement was on the order of months, but that is really, uh, for the whole group. It’s hard to call the individuals outta that. Um, so that’s kind of the baseline that we know. Um. And, those drugs, you know, they have side effects that we need to manage, but that’s kind of would be the next treatment that’s standard treatment. It’s approved by the FDA because of the survival improvement. The new finding about this new drug, they’re called “PARP” inhibitors. A group did a study in England where they had fifty guys who had some DNA mutation, mostly BRCA2. They treated the fifty guys; sixteen had mutations. And, they found that none of the people without the mutations responded. Fourteen of the sixteen - so, you know, ninety percent who had a mutation responded to these drugs very well. Suggesting, they’re probably going to work really well in patients like that. Um. Patient: Am I one of those people? Doctor: Yeah, you’re one of those people. Now, that drug hasn’t been through the big paces of FDA trial approval. That’s where it is right now. So, the trials we’re looking at are looking at giving that drug alone or in combination with these standard hormones. So, the trial that I would consider for you have multiple arms. We could talk about that in detail, but, it’s there’s two different trials they could either combine the drugs or give you one drug. Um. But, the, but the, where the field is moving is there’s going to be fifty trials of this to try to nail this down.

Family Member: If it’s okay with you, I mean… Doctor: Yeah it’s okay with me. Family Member: He’s a good guy. Doctor: Uh huh, Yeah I think he’s excellent. I haven’t talked to him in a long time, but he and I are close. We used to talk all the time. Family Member: Okay. Gives you a good reason for you to get back together (Laughs) Doctor: M____. Family Member: He’s at M___ because I worked there. Doctor: That used to be C____> Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Mm,hmm. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Will you make your own appointment with him? Family Member: I can. I mean whatever I need to do, just let me know. I’ll do it. (pause)

Patient: Oh, man! Doctor: When push comes to shove, and this is reeeeaaaalllly bad. Patient: Doc, I was just talkin’ about the piss bag. Doctor: I know, but your other problem is the poop! Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Even if you re-route the piss bag, you may not be able to get away from not re-routing the poop. It just depends. Patient: Because it’s – Doctor: It’s connected! Patient: Connected, and then it’ll still be goin’ in the pad, and if it go – Doctor: So, I’m sayin’ – Patient: In that pad in that area. Doctor: I know you. I would rather that you know there’s a potential of two bags.

Patient: My hormone shot. Doctor: I don’t know if you – if you get a hormone shot in January and it’s six months, you won’t need another one until July. So, that April version will just be a PSA check and see how we’re doing Patient: Right. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And maybe some more discussion. Family Member: Because that will be at least his third hormone shot. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: And at some point, everybody’s saying those will stop working or could stop working. Doctor: They could stop working. Um. They will stop working eventually. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I mean, usually, it takes a year or two. But, they will stop eventually. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. That may be the biggest, huh, roadblock. It says have a known history of hepatitis C infection. Huh, it is one of the things that would make it so that you can’t do the style, the study. I can still give you the chemo, huh, but it may be that you’re not eligible for the trial because of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Some of that we just have to check with the study team, huh, to see that this is up to date, huh, or not. I don’t have a paperclip. I’m going to check before you head out to see if I can get one for you. Huh, but again, we’ll have to see whether this one makes sense for you or not because of the hep C stuff. It doesn’t mean I can’t give you the chemo. It may be from a trial thing, you’re not allowed to do it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we also, the other thing you might need a blood transfusion to become eligible, huh, so we’ll have to keep an eye on that one too, if we had to do that. Huh, so let’s go over your medicines. So you said that, huh, your ibuprofen was written on February nineteenth. You have no refills. Patient: Right. Doctor: Do you need a refill? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And then, huh, and then you have, and then the morphine you said right now you don’t need it? And how many ibuprofen do you take a day? Patient: Well, (laughs) Doctor: Four to six a day. Every six hours you can take it, so that would be, that’s thirty, (pause) Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, a good question. It’s something that I have to always make sure people understand. At this stage in the game you should never be on a placebo only trial. Like it can never be either drug X or you’re crap out of luck. No, that’s never gonna happen. Okay? Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: And if anybody ever offers you that, that’s bad news. That’s just ethically wrong. So, we have a lot of watchdogs, safeguards, everybody’s looking to make sure that we don’t do something like that. Patient: Okay, Alright. Doctor: Yeah, keep going. Patient: I’ll get these tests done and then we’ll come back to see you. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Patient: And then the rest is done here? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: The treatment is here? Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: I’ll go with that line of action first. Doctor: And then you’re going to say, boy, that doctor, she’s really smart. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Be sure you don’t like, you know, sleep so hard that you forget to pee if you actually have to pee. Doctor: I’m just saying seven p.m. Okay. Bye. Patient: Okay. So I got – she took – oh, I do, right here. Doctor: You do have sheet to go. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Alright. See you guys soon.

Family Member: I thought Hopkins was doing it. Patient: I don’t know, recall, if it was Hopkins. Doctor: No. It wasn’t. But I can tell you about it. So your color thing said there was nothing. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: From the, the genes that they tested. Patient: Right. Doctor: Which was like thirty. Patient: That there was no, there was no connection to prostate cancer in my genetic history? Doctor: Yeah. So these, these thirty genes or so that they test for, which are kind of very important cancer genes, you didn’t have any mutations of them. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: The uh, so the apricot seed. There was thing called, laetrile. Patient: Right.

Patient: No. Family Member: No. Patient: No. Uh-uh. No. We, we had to drive that far to get there, but- Doctor: Did you stay like in a hotel or where did you stay at? Family Member: It was in a hotel. Then they get the bus to pick up at the hotel, then it takes you to the, uh, park, and then you get in this- Patient: You get in those little trucks. Family Member: Open trucks. Doctor: I have a patient, one of my patients is a guy with a lot of money, and he and his wife do this. But, you know, they do it like only people with a lot of money can do it. Patient: Right. (Laughter) Doctor: And he’s like, oh, yeah, we’re going and we stay in these tents. Patient: Oh, you can. Doctor: And his wife’s like, yeah, they’re not really tents, though. They like have king-size bed. You know? They’re like-

Doctor: Okay? So, we’ll give it a couple of weeks for you to heal up, get over this. Then, we will get back on the chemotherapy. Okay? Doctor: Mmm,hmm Patient: By my name. Don’t accept it and call the police.” Doctor: Okay Patient: I say, “What you do? Call the police.” I say, “I’m gonna make a police report. Call the police.” ‘Cuz whoever, if somebody tried to come in and, and fill up scripts. Doctor: Okay Patient: ‘Cuz see, I don’t know how I got careless, and, and, but I keep a lot of stuff in my pockets. When it happened before where I was. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So, I did like I said, did like I told her and she been like I told you (Miss F_ and I said) Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: And call me. Let my daughter know and let me know.” ‘Cuz I’m sure I’m gonna press charges. I swear to God, I’m gonna press charges. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. So, what happened then? Did they give you the medication? Patient: Huh?

Family Member: Do you have the results of today’s draw, blood draw? Doctor: I was told that he did not have blood drawn. Did he have it? Family Member: Yeah. Oh, yeah. Doctor: Yeah. No. I don’t, then. I’ll, uh, check. I’ll bring you the results. I don’t think I have a PSA back. Family Member: Oh. Right. Doctor: But, uh- Patient: So what, what involves, getting a shot every month or so? Doctor: Every six weeks, if you go on it. Patient: Every six weeks? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Hum. Well, what happens if I wanted to go to England and get it or Germany? Doctor: You’re a free man. You can go any time.

Patient: Exactly. Doctor: So you know radiation is tough. It helps the pain but it’s always something for something, Patient: Yeah. Doctor: not something for nothing, so there’s some side effects there. And you got a lot of radiation. Patient: So the question there being then probably safe to go back on the supplements? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: On some of them. I would gradually reintroduce them if I was you. Doctor: Yes. I agree with you. Patient: And I also had a question about that proton treatment that they have in B___. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: Um Doctor: Not ah truly applicable to you at this point. That’s great for if you were just newly diagnosed with your prostate cancer or if you have some specific area on your spine. You obviously just got the radiation to there but if you know you’re a baby, for example, and you had a really tiny spinal cord, and you have this cancer next to it, a proton would be the perfect treatment. For adults, it’s a little harder to know what is better than the standard. So you know you hope maybe if you got protons you wouldn’t have had so many side effects. That’s possible. But it’s not as mainstream I think as we’d like to see it. At some point now when they’re really up and running and more patients will get experience, we’ll probably get a better sense of that. But for now I think you’ve got the best treatment which was those three areas in the spine and then your pelvis. Family Member: But is this proton more precise than-?
